Princess Shuri from the MCU film Black Panther
can be simply be
described as the genius.

A master engineer, scientist and intellect,
this prodigy is known for leading the Wakandan

Design Group in
creating their modern technologies including

weaponry, defenses,
transportation and communication.

What if I told you that her taste in
music might also be maverick?

Today we’re gonna going into the afrofuturistic
sounds of Wakanda – a
genre we call Gqom.

Gqom is a South African Electronic Dance Music
(EDM) genre birthed in

the hoods and townships of the East Coast
city of Durban, in the

KwaZulu-Natal province in the dawn of the
2010s.

From its early days
of pumping in minibus taxis in and around

cites to attract customers
to choose their rides over the competition

and distribution via file
sharing sites and apps like the now discontinued

BBM and current
messaging giant WhatsApp, Gqom has seen humongous

traction and has
gained prominence beyond the expectations

of many spawning scenes all
over the world.

This cybernetic genre is often described as
dark, minimalist and

menacing – a direct aural representation
of the people who first

created it who historical and currently live
in poverty despite the

promises brought with the wake of democracy
in the country in 1994
when Nelson Mandela was elected president.

Gqom has four mains elements (there is an
optional fifth but we’ll get
to that a little later for now, the four are:

A low deep drone [Drone noise]
2.

Vintage-like instrumentation [tambourine hit]
3.

Futuristic synthesizers [futuristic synths
play]
Vocal ad-libs and utterances [Woza, HAYI!]

This music, represents who she is.

See the very language that she speaks, Wakandan,

isiXhosa language South Africa language – part

When you listen to the inner workings of the

The broken drum beat – the broken trust
that the youth have in the

things that have come before them

Youth looks forward.

This Afrofuturistic idea of taking what is
